unnormalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices
normalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices

unnormalised: My journey with yoga started, like many others, with a frantic search for stress relief. The daily grind in Mumbai – the honking taxis, the deadlines at the office, even the simple act of navigating Dadar station – left me feeling perpetually frayed. A friend, Priya, suggested I try a class at the local Iyengar Yoga Institute. Honestly, I was skeptical. I’d seen the impossibly flexible poses on Instagram and thought, "That’s not for me!".
normalised: My journey with yoga started, like many others, with a frantic search for stress relief. The daily grind in Mumbai – the honking taxis, the deadlines at the office, even the simple act of navigating Dadar station – left me feeling perpetually frayed. A friend, Priya, suggested I try a class at the local Iyengar Yoga Institute. Honestly, I was skeptical. I’d seen the impossibly flexible poses on Instagram and thought, "That’s not for me!".

unnormalised: But Priya persisted, and I'm so glad she did. The first class was humbling. I couldn't even touch my toes! But the instructor, a gentle woman named Radha, emphasized proper alignment and breathing – pranayama – over achieving perfect poses. She talked about Patanjali's Yoga Sutras and the eight limbs of yoga, a philosophy that extended far beyond the asanas.

unnormalised: Slowly, I started incorporating yoga into my daily routine. A simple 15-minute sun salutation (Surya Namaskar) in the morning before heading to work made a world of difference. I learned to appreciate the stillness, the quiet connection with my breath. The physical benefits were a pleasant surprise too. My back pain, a constant companion from sitting at a desk for 8 hours a day, started to ease. I even managed to increase my apartment space perception – somehow 500 sq ft felt much bigger!

I even managed to increase my apartment space perception – somehow five hundred square feet felt much bigger!

unnormalised: Now, I explore different styles. Sometimes, I attend a Vinyasa flow class at a studio near my home in Bandra. Other times, I follow online videos focusing on restorative yoga. Recently, I've even considered a weekend retreat in Rishikesh, the yoga capital of the world, to deepen my practice. Dr. Sharma, my family physician, recommended it for better sleep and overall well-being.

unnormalised: Yoga isn't just about bending and stretching. It's about finding that inner shanti, that peaceful center amidst the chaos of life. It’s about connecting with your body and mind on a deeper level. And for me, it’s a journey I’m only just beginning. Even the Rs. 5000 expense for the new yoga mat felt like an investment in my health!
